article.description:
Chevy Troutman repeatedly powered through
undersized Robert Morris for easy baskets to score 24 points and
No. 2 Pittsburgh bounced back from its first loss with an 85-49
victory Saturday.
article.headline: Troutman scores 24 points to lead No. 2 Pittsburgh
article.linkText: No. 2 Pittsburgh bounces back from first loss with rout
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- After cruising through one of the softest early season schedules in the country, except for a loss in the lone tight game they've played, the Pitt Panthers got a warning from their coach. It won't be this way again the rest of season. Chevy Troutman repeatedly powered through undersized Robert Morris for easy baskets to score 24 points and No. 2 Pittsburgh bounced back from its first loss with an 85-49 victory Saturday. Pitt, barely getting a workout before Monday night's Big East opener against No. 6 Notre Dame, is 22-0 against Robert Morris and 55-0 against Northeast Conference schools. "Now it's all about the Big East,'' coach Ben Howland said. "It's the most important part of the schedule and there are no breathers. Every game in the Big East is a testament to that.'' Starting with Notre Dame, the only team to beat Pitt twice last year during the Panthers' 29-6 season. Notre Dame improved to 12-1 by beating Valparaiso 55-53 Saturday. Pitt, which will be facing its first ranked opponent, plays its final 16 regular-season games in the conference. The Panthers (10-1), coming off a 79-67 loss to Georgia that is bound to drop them in next week's Top 25, overwhelmed Robert Morris with their size and strength in opening up first-half leads of as many as 27 points. "That game is history,'' Pitt's Ontario Lett said of the loss to Georgia. "We said in the locker room after the game we had to learn from it and get better. Hopefully, we'll see them later (in the NCAA Tournament). But there's nothing we can do about it now.'' Just as Robert Morris could do nothing to combat Pittsburgh inside. "When you lose by 40 and the other team makes only one 3-pointer, that's hard to do,'' Robert Morris coach Mark Schmidt said. "They've got a better team and better players and they just overwhelmed us. I told our players that if we played the game between the foul lines, we didn't have a chance.'' The 6-foot-7 Troutman, who matched Robert Morris' tallest starter, hadn't scored more than 15 points this season, but outscored Robert Morris by himself 19-13 as Pittsburgh cruised to a 39-13 halftime lead. He missed only one of 12 shots and was 2-for-2 at the free-throw line. "The thing I like about this team is it's so unselfish,'' Howland said. "Early in the second half, I heard Julius (Page) say to Chevy, `We're going to try to get you 40.' It's a team thing. Everybody's sharing the ball and passing.'' Lett, far more physical than anyone in Robert Morris' undersized frontcourt, added 18 points and seven rebounds and Jaron Brown had 10 points and 11 rebounds. Pitt's frontcourt outscored Robert Morris' 62-18 as Troutman and Lett were a combined 20-of-22 shooting. Pitt shot 63.1 percent (41-of-65). "It was like practice, we go at people if we've got a mismatch,'' Troutman said. "We just kept getting open.'' DaMarcus Ellis had 11 points for the Colonials (3-6), who were overwhelmed even though Pitt forward Donatas Zavackas (sprained ankle) didn't play. He is expected to be ready Monday. With Pitt so dominant up front, it hardly mattered that Pitt star point guard Brandin Knight had another ineffective game offensively with four points. He had nine assists. Knight, a third-team All-America last season, has 21 points in three games since scoring a season-high 22 against Rhode Island on Dec. 21. The Panthers tightened up defensively after allowing Georgia to shoot 54 percent against them, 20 percent higher than their season average, by holding Robert Morris to 29.2 percent shooting (19-of-65). Pitt also outrebounded the Colonials 51-25. Robert Morris followed up a 76-59 defeat to Penn State with an even worse loss, its fourth in a row and fifth in six games since starting 3-1. The Colonials were never in it, trailing 9-0 while being held scoreless for 3½ minutes. They never got closer than five points after that while being outscored 28-7 over the final 14:49 of the first half.
